_header: Lord God all-wielding / I beteach today into Thy hand
_description: A general morning prayer — in couplets

BLEge3245.First Lines: And lord god al weldandeI beteche today in þy hande…
BLEge3245.Last Lines: …And lat vs neuere parte fro thegraunt vs lord þat it so be
BLEge3245.Note: 18 lines. Written as if part of 424.
BLEge3245.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “The Gurney Series of Religious Lyrics.” 
             PMLA
         54 (1939): 369-90: 376.

Lincoln91.First Lines:
Lorde god alweldandeI beteche to daye in to þi
                    hande…
Lincoln91.Last Lines:
…Alls thow for vs died one a treeGraunte vs lorde þat swa
                    beeAmen Amen par charite
Lincoln91.Note:
20 lines, written 2-3 verse lines per line of MS; immediately follows
                        424 as if same
                    text.
Lincoln91.Facsimiles:
Brewer,  Derek Stanley,  and  A. E. B. Owen.  
             “Introduction.” 
             The Thornton Manuscript (Lincoln Cathedral MS. 91).
         London: Scolar Press, 1975.
Lincoln91.Editions:
Horstmann,  Carl,
                        ed.  
             Yorkshire Writers.
         2 vols. London, Sonnenschein; New York: Macmillan, 1895-96: 1.364 (and cf. 1.222).
Perry,  George G.,
                        ed.  
             Religious Pieces in Prose and Verse from R. Thornton’s
                MS.
EETS
         o.s. 26 (1867); repr. 1973: 77.
Comper,  Frances M. M. 
             The Life of Richard Rolle, Together with an Edition of his English
                Lyrics.
         London: J. M. Dent, 1928, 1933; New York: E. P. Dutton, 1929: 294.

PULKane21.First Lines:
Lord god alweldandI beteche in to þin
                    hande…
PULKane21.Last Lines:
…And lat vs neuer departe fro þeAls þow for vs deyde
                    on a rode treAnd graunt vs lord þat itte so beAmen amen for
                    charite
PULKane21.Editions:
Bühler,  Kurt. 
             “A Middle English Versified Prayer to the Trinity.” 
             Modern Language Notes
         66 (1951): 312-14: 314.
